column1: Never before has such a poorly written book received such acclaim. Maya Angelou wrote this story not with candor and grace but with a bias rarely allowed to sit on shelves let alone the top of a best-seller list. She was not humorous but had a heinousness of character and action that places her beyond the limits of human pity. This "inspiring author" did not demonstrate poignancy and depth but the crude rudiments of writing skill below that found in the essays of a primary school student.               Maya Angelou has portrayed herself as a victim of fate and yet at best her actions can only be described as foolhardy. In an attempt to prove to herself that she isn't a lesbian (a term she apparently doesn't understand) she initiates a deed without thinking of the consequences. She repeatedly gratifies her ego by exalting her academic accomplishments
column2: yet doesn't grasp the fallacies of her own actions until it is far too late.             Several fans have seen her as an example to women. I must disagree with this ardently. Every teenage girl using her as a role model and demonstrating such lack of forethought puts herself at risk for sexual assualt
column3: neglect
column4: STDs
column5: and teen pregnancy.             My only hope for this book is a quick and discreet cremation. May her name never be mentioned in the same breath as Margaret Atwood or any other great modern writer of either gender
column6: and ANY nationality

column1: This book provides an intriguing look back at a time when the Dot Com Boom was at its zenith
column2: shortly before the crash. Interestingly
column3: there is no sense of the impending doom that lies just over the horizon.  Lewis' "Liar's Poker" was extremely enjoyable
column4: particularly because of the flash and personality of the central players. In this book
column5: Lewis seems to have lost his way as he tries to wring interest from a much less compelling or likable chief character. The tone of the book is further weakened by the constant labels applied to Clark's disciples as the "smartest
column6: best
column7: greatest
column8: and most ingenious
column9:
individuals in their various fields.  What strains credibility, however, is the attribution of all Clark's successes to his incredible intelligence and foresight, while the fault of his failures is cast on the incompetent actions and short-sighted beliefs of others. History will probably not judge Clark as charitably as Lewis -- especially since most of the Clark's companies have either failed outright or remain but shells of their Dot Com era glory (most notably SGI, Netscape, and Healtheon).  Throughout the book, Jim Clark is touted for wealth that amounts to between $3 and $4 billion. The list of 2004 Forbes 400 Richest in America shows Jim Clark with an approximated net worth of $700 million. For a man who brags he will quit making money when his fortune eclipses that of Oracle's Larry Ellison, today Clark probably most regrets the loss of his favorite designation: billionaire.  
 This has to be the most boring book I have ever read. Well, I haven't quite finished it yet as it's taking forever to push my way through it. And I'm sure that more boring books exist, I just haven't read them.    I wanted to learn about KKR and LBOs - particularly as a division of KKR recently bought one of the vendors supplying my own employer. I was hoping for the big picture of what took place as well as some entertaining anecdotes. But this book consists largely of page after page of uninteresting minutiae of conversations between the various parties involved. There really is no need for such detail and a little bit of editing could have halved the size of the book without losing any essential information. And a bit of theoretical discussion would have been far more valuable than some of the biographical material. It felt a bit like watching someone else's home video. It probably means a lot to the people involved, especially as they'll get the in jokes and quirks of the participants, but it's painfully boring for strangers forced to watch it out of politeness.  I'm sure that much of the conversation is fiction anyway. People don't reliably remember this level of detail of converstaions over a period of years. What are remembered are broad brushstrokes - and this is what the author should have written.  There are occasional moments of entertainment - like Ted Forstmann obsessing about the evils of junk bonds. But most of the characters seem quite flat and uninteresting.   The fact is: I wanted some of this information in this book. As it provided some of this, albeit with a lot of suffering on my part, I'll give it two stars.  Update: Well I did finish this book eventually. My final opinion is much the same 
 This MAN does not understand estrogen at all. It is sad that so many women are apparently putting their health into his hands. The reason why so many women and good clinicians are avoiding products like Tri-est is because these products don't feed our bodies the necessary estrogens that our bodies actually produce from our ovaries. Giving women estriol and estrone just blocks our receptors from receiving the necessary and most important E2-estradiol. Our bodies will then metabolize the E2 into the others naturally. Research supports this aspect clearly. The other thing about this guy and his book is that he bounces everything he says off of premarin studies and does not keep the information flow consistent one way or another.  Most women getting on bio-identical hormones these days have never used premarin and want good research or clinical comparatives to support their choices with regards to bio-identicals. This book does not provide either good knowledge or research. Additionally, this book is quite disappointing for one that Amazon places so highly in their search engine.  Instead, I would recommend Wiley's book for the radical approach to understanding what it is we actually want to achieve with our bio-identicals, and Reiss's book for good information on how to monitor ourselves when using bio-identicals. However, Reiss, (another boy doctor) is also a proponent of Tri-est, probably because its just easier for him to prescribe.  Once our female clinicians have really worked out the bio-identicals that are working well for us, then we will all have great data to support our choices. In the meantime, avoid this book

column4: mistress South America's most enigmatic and charismatic tyrant
column5: should have provided us with cutural and personal insights beyond a standard history text book.  For example
column6: I would have liked to have finished this book with an understanding of how Francisco Solano Lopez managed to inspire 60% to 80% (depending on your source) of his country's inhabitants to die in a war which had absolutely no rationale.  Instead
column7: I got a good solid dose of the Latin Lover.  Tuck did her research
column8: but not to a greater degree than any high school student.  At no point in the story did I gain an understanding of the causes of the war

column10: the constant power vacillations of post-independence South America

This is as unforgivable in a historical novel as failing to develop the characters (a feat which Tuck also manages to accomplish!).  Not only did Tuck do a slap dab job with South American history

column16: and many stress their adoptive connections to the parent culture.  (A good experience for them if it actually happened

column18: supposedly kept within these families and tribes for centuries

Some of the more honest books on shamanism admit they are witholding certain information because some knowledge *should* be kept 'in the family'.  They openly say they are creating something for use by people living in the modern age.  Wolfe has done none of this. Waste of time to read.  Waste of space on my bookshelf.  Waste of trees to print it.  Waste of *plastic* for the bag I carried it home in.  I'd be embarrassed to even turn this thing to a used bookstore for credit.

column1: In her book
column2: Kathleen Brown offers a revision of colonial Virginia history. Relying almost entirely upon previously known and explored primary materials
column3: she constructs an argument that gender heavily influenced colonial development.        Breaking her book up chronologically into three parts
column4: Brown focuses first on England and the Virginia colony's early days. In discussing the former
column5: she establishes the role of women who adhere to social behavioral norms as that of good wives
column6: and those who do not adhere to those norms as nasty wenches. In the case of Virginia
column7: she explores the role of women in English society vis a vis Powhatan's Algonquian society. When Powhatan offered women to English settlers
column8: whether for marriage or a night's enjoyment
column9: he did so for political reasons; the settlers
column10: however
column11: thought Indians valued women less
column12: and differently
column13: than they did. Settlers further grappled with the fact that women farmed while men
column14: they thought
column15: took it easy
column16: hunting and fishing.        The second part focuses on the change in roles of women
column17: and the corresponding change in how men though of them. As Virginia became more permanent
column18: and as slaves became more prevalent
column19: "good wives" came to mean the elite women
column20: whereas "nasty wenches" meant servant or non-elite women. Following Bacon's Rebellion
column21: this labeling shifted somewhat as elite men attempted to break the unofficial alliance between black slaves and white servants. Principally
column22: the violations of white women that formerly would have made them nasty wenches now were less serious
column23: while those same violations of black women were more so.        The last part explores the domination of men and the lives of elite women. Men became much more patriarchal
column24: establishing social norms and laws to that effect. They were "anxious" in the sense that they were now required to hold domination over their wives
column25: families
column26: and farms
column27: and maintain strict adherence to those norms and laws. Relying heavily on the writings of William Byrd II and Landon Carter
column28: Brown points out the fears these men had of declining virility
column29: disobedient sons
column30: and the like. Women
column31: meanwhile
column32: came together against their husbands
column33: quietly undermining them on occasions
column34: especially in discipline issues
column35: and generally developing a women's society of tea parties and such.        On the one hand
column36: Brown's revisionist attempt is a worthwhile endeavor; only the foolish would say women had no role or impact whatsoever in colonial development. As historians have largely ignored or downplayed this role
column37: her study is therefore relevant. On the other hand
column38: she delves far too deeply into the sex lives of leading men. Her study was not one solely of the role of gender
column39: but also of sexuality. To a certain and very limited extent that exploration is worthwhile-certainly the colonists were concerned with fornication
column40: bastardy and the like-but do I
column41: the reader
column42: really need to know on which days Byrd gave his wife a "flourish
column43: and whether or not he was vigorous"? No. Furthermore
column44: certain inherent flaws exist in a reinterpretation that relies heavily on modern and liberal views of sex and sexuality. Consequently
column45: there are certain aspects of the book that are worth reading
column46: but one should select those aspects carefully.

column5: kaftan-wearing

column9: other than humorously swatting some flies

column13: or he's spent half his book shooting fish in a barrel. That might seem like good sport
column14: but before long it becomes obvious it's a cheap thrill.  Having said that
column15: I sincerely doubt that the titillation of seeing dumb French Feminists taken apart is what made this book such a splash: I think it's because of Sokal's purported intent: to undermine the notion of cognitive relativism
column16: especially as it associated with modern philosophy of science
column17: in particular the work of Thomas Kuhn and Paul Feyerabend. This is the battle: Sokal aligns with those who say scientists are the exclusive purveyors of a shining light called truth; the Barbarians at the gate are these simpering postmodernists who want to tear the temple down.  While the poseurs cited in this book are certainly (for the most part) phoneys or idiots
column18: I think Thomas Kuhn was neither
column19: and while Paul Feyerabend overplayed the court jester hand
column20: he had some important things to say too.  So
column21: to the first point: Proving that one writer (or a hundred
column22: or a thousand) who purports to adhere to relativism is a charlatan doesn't establish anything about *the idea* of relativism. All you have established is that you have a found yourself a charlatan. Give yourself a star.   But while you're pinning it on
column23: remember that postmodernists do not have a monopoly on illogical
column24: bamboozling
column25: balderdash:  Example: Sir Roger Penrose (Emeritus Rouse Ball professor of mathematics at Oxford University
column26: no less) and his dreadful
column27: lumpen-headed
column28: and deliberately bamboozling anti-AI tract "The Emperor's New Mind". The very point of the (no doubt correct but nonetheless entirely irrelevant) science deluged on the reader in that book is to obscure the fact that the real emperor was Roger Penrose and his arguments on AI really blow the kumara.   Example: Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker's Linguistic Nativism
column29: which has held sway for a good thirty years in many linguistics departments
column30: and is anything but post-modern: nativism holds that humans have an innate understanding of grammar hard wired into their biology. From my paltry readings in linguistics and the philosophy of language
column31: my impression is that Pinker's and Chomsky's arguments are seriously flawed. (See: Sampson: "The Language Instinct Debate" for a thorough linguistic critique of nativism; see Rorty: "Contingency Irony
column32: and Solidarity" for a philosophical perspective on the contingency of language). Make note of this example
column33: as it becomes relevant later on.  Secondly
column34: Sokal and Bricmont (quite deliberately) refuse to engage on certain topics
column35: in particular on cultural or aesthetic relativism
column36: which they say (without providing a reason) "raise very different issues". Take that star away
column37: for this statement betrays a fundamental misunderstanding about relativism. Actually
column38: ethical
column39: aesthetic and cognitive relativisms raise different manifestations of *exactly* the same issue: Cognitive relativism
column40: in that it relates to "epistemic" truth (as opposed to "moral" truth or "aesthetic" truth - both of which seem intuitively more questionable ideas) is simply a cut closer to the quick: indeed
column41: the aesthetic and moral brands of relativism rely for their plausibility on cognitive relativism anyway (i.e. if the truths we understand about the physical universe are contingent on our language
column42: then it follows that ideals of right and wrong and beauty must be similarly contingent on our language).  Thirdly
column43: Sokal provides the following account of cognitive relativism:   "While scientists ... try to obtain an objective view ... of the world
column44: relativist thinkers tell them that they are wasting their time and that such an enterprise is
column45: in principle
column46: an illusion"  Now that
column47: to put it mildly
column48: is a *very* punchy version of relativism
column49: and not one that any credible relativist philosopher I know of (and certainly not Thomas Kuhn
column50: who spent a whole book explaining how and why the process scientific discovery works) subscribes to.  That is
column51: in the trade
column52: known as a straw-man argument: You set it up to knock it over. Here goes:   P1: Relativists say science is a waste of time P2: Science helps us reliably predict and react coherently to phenomena occurring in the world  P3: Things which help to predict and react to such phenomena have genuine utility  C1: Therefore
column53: science has genuine utility C2: Ergo
column54: science is not a waste of time  Case closed. Is relativism dead? No: the problem is
column55: most relativists I know would completely agree with all of the above argument except for premise 1. The cat is most definitely still out of the bag. (In a nutshell
column56: all reasonably stated relativism says is that you can't know that your theory actually maps onto the actual configuration of the outside world; it may
column57: it may not: logically there will always be some other possible explanation for the same set of data
column58: however implausible or difficult to imagine
column59: and in part that difficulty in imagination may be a function of the historical contingency of our belief in
column60: and description of the world in terms of
column61: the current "paradigm". Relativism simply says the best you can do is to know that
column64: not that it is *true*. Though Sokal and Bricmont may disagree
column65: I don't think this is controversial amongst philosophers nor
column68: in criticising an admittedly utterly ludicrous passage bestowed on the world by that splendidly silly feminist philosopher Sylvia Kristeva
column69: Sokal makes the following footnote:  "...Kristeva seems to be appealing ... to the 'Sapir-Whorf thesis' in linguistics that is ...that our language radically conditions our view of the world. This thesis nowadays is sharply criticised by some linguists: see
column70: for example Pinker ..."  Hold the phone. The implication is that the Sapir-Whorf thesis (as to the contingency of language) has been discredited
column71: but by none other than Steven Pinker in his "The Language Instinct" which
column73: is at the very least a controversial piece of writing. This is an extremely important point
column74: since it's utterly central to the credibility of the anti-relativist cause
column75: and if one takes Geoffrey Sampson's book (cited above) at face value the nativist claims themselves are built on very suspect reasoning and scientific research. It seems to me (and to writers like Richard Rorty) that language must radically condition our view of the world
column76: because that's the only basis on which we can even describe it.  At the end of the day
column77: properly stated cognitive relativism is no a threat to modern scientific discourse
column78: except that it relegates the scientist from "truth knower" or "person through whom you may have exclusive access to the truth" (sounds a bit like a grand high pooh-bah or - dare I say it - high priest
column79: doesn't it?) to "person whose theory works the best for now" and who may be in competition for that status with other people in the community whether or not they're scientists.   If science *does* work better than feng shui or healing crystals (and I
column81: think it does) then this shouldn't be a particularly troubling way of looking at the world for a scientist who is at ease with his views and his value to the community. So it makes the knee-jerk reactions against relativism
column82: from the likes of Sokal and elsewhere Richard Dawkins
column83: all the more mystifying.  Olly Buxton

column1: I had a hard time putting the book down.  I kept reading hoping the book would reveal some item beyond the obvious.  Schmitt spends 200 pages explaining that customer experience should be at the forefront when launching a new product or designing a marketing campaign.  I dare say Schmitt would be hard pressed to find a CEO that doesn't taut the value of good customer experience or the importance of retaining customers.  Where Schmitt falls drastically short is tying customer experience activities to financial decisions companies make every day.  This is perhaps the largest challenge those of us in customer retention or customer marketing face every day.  It is great to ascertain that companies should improve customer support to provide a better customer experience to retain more customers.  However
column2: how does a manager position a $200
column3: 000 call center upgrade vs. a $200
column4: 000 product enhancement?  According to Schmitt both are valuable in the Customer Experience framework.  With limited lip service to "regression modeling" and "customer surveys" there is no valuable guidance to help a customer experience focused manager position their projects against other expenditures within a company.  Schmitt could take a few pages out of Jim Collins' work to better tie customer experience initiatives to corporate financial success.

column1: If you picked up this book to help you build your existing business or build a new one

McDonalds is a great success and one to be looked at carefully but not for the reasons he points out. It's apparent he has not been in a McDonalds all that often. He mentions that at McDonalds they depend on consistancy at all their chains. For example the fries stay in the fryer for ten minutes "a soggy french fry is not a McDonald's french fry". At any McDonalds a customer knows what to expect. Then he goes into mention that this is why McDonalds chain resturant is more successfull than those businesses that depend on trade name recognition. I'm sorry this throws a red flag. People eat there beacuse it is fast and it is [not expensive}

I admit that I am not the smartest business person but its clear Michael Gerber isn't either

column1: The problem with this book is that it doesn't adress important issues facing our legal system today. If for example Ford motor company manufactures a SUV with a faultly shock system that fails and causes the truck to roll over resulting in serious injury or death
column2: clearly we have an open and shut case where Ford is completely liable and you can certainly bet that Ford is going to make sure that problem never happens again. But that's obvious. Anyone who knows little to nothing about the law understands full well that a company who is found to have a faulty product will increase their standards and work feverishly to fix the product in order to prevent future legal action. Carl T. Bogus has taken simple ideas like those and twisted them around to create a driving force for his political agenda
column3: and baseless political agenda no less.   "And although the public was largely unaware of it
column4: George W. Bush's 'tort reform'-which seeks to constrict the ability of individuals to sue corporations-was a major factor in his raising unprecedented sums for his presidential candidacy." The public? Carl you're a law professor at an over priced
column5: second rate university in the middle of Rhode Island. How does that give you a divine right to claim that you know more than the average person about the Bush administration and allow you to make an accusation like that based on no fact at all? Where are the fact checkers at NYU press anyways?    To the contrary when George W. Bush is speaking in terms of tort reform he is referring to torts that actually need reform. Let's look at Johnny Edwards (former vice presidential running mate to John Kerry) who specializes in malpractice suits specifically involving children born with cerebral palsy. He claims that if doctors had immediately performed Caesarean sections then the babies would have been spared the affliction. The results of such lawsuits have yielded 4 times as many C-sections performed since 1970
column6: yet the number of children born with cerebral palsy has remained constant. In fact cerebral palsy is linked to fetal brain injury long before labor begins. Edwards has avoided cases where the children died at birth because typically juries only award roughly $500
column7: 000 in those situations. In 1985 Edwards was on a case dealing with a girl named Jennifer Campbell
column8: a 5 year old with cerebral palsy
column9: which ended up being an award of 6.5 million dollars for the plaintiffs. This is what president Bush means by "tort reform". In simple terms someone who spills a cup of hot coffee on themselves while pulling away from a drive through window should NOT be awarded any type of damage. Cases like these undermine the goals of the framers of the Constitution of the United States of America and place individuals freedoms in jeopardy. We have seesaws vanishing from playgrounds
column10: emergency-room staff blocked from attending to patients off hospital grounds even if they can see them bleeding to death just 30 feet away

column1: This was Heinlein's 1st novel; it wasn't published during his lifetime.  He wrote it prior to WWII.  It's emphasis is on his depression-era socio-political views
column2: not on science fiction entertainment.  Thus
column3: the plot is thin & the characters
column4: though likable
column5: aren't deeply drawn.  To his credit
column6: he changed many of his views later--as many were rather naive &
column7: perhaps
column8: influenced by his frustration.  Some of his libertarian social innovations
column9: however
column10: were courageous & innovative
column11: but would require considerable cultural development to become politically practical in the US.  But many (IMHO boring) pages are devoted to his economic/financial system
column12: particularly the "card game" attacking free enterprise.  It is very naive--ignores intellectual capital
column13: population expansion
column14: & the money multiplier (the average dollar's spent 6x/year).  His "social credit/dividend" system is utopian to an extreme & p. 243: "We don't need social service workers where poverty is unknown" is absurd--$ won't buy a child's mental/emotional health anymore than happiness.  Heinlein fans (he's my favorite SF novelist) may find it historically/developmentally enlightening
column15: but as fiction
column16: it's his worst novel

column1: Schneiderman's "Leonardo's Laptop" is singularly disappointing.  Promising to raise our expectation of what we should get from technology
column2: he instead uses a forced extended metaphor in the form of Leonardo da Vinci.  What would Leonardo do?
column3: we are repeatedly asked.  Schneiderman attempts to answer the question.  Sadly
column4: his answers are neither new nor groundbreaking.  I cannot believe that Leonardo would simply recount solutions that are already available and attempt to make such solutions sound visionary and forward-thinking.  The chapters in the book discuss the issues with usability today
column5: activites and relationships
column6: and attempt to discuss future directions in several fields: government
column7: healthcare
column8: business
column9: and education.  In these chapters
column10: Schneiderman uses feel-good buzzwords like 'empowering' and 'enabling'
column11: but never moves beyond the feel-good buzzwords to suggest real solutions.  In most cases
column12: he suggests solutions that are already implemented; in others
column13: he simply waves his hands at the problem and says that there has to be a solution.  Each chapter concludes with a skeptic's corner.  This section could easily be re-labelled the strawman's corner.  In that section
column14: he constructs arguments that skeptics might use
column15: but he must assume that skeptics are uniformly moronic.  The so-called skeptical arguments are drawn with exceptionally rough strokes
column16: which he dispenses of with little regard to very real concerns that can and should be discussed.    I had high hopes for this book.  I wanted something that pushed the boundaries.  I wanted something visionary.  Instead
column17: I got a repetitive book that somehow didn't say anything.  I can only hope that future works give us something better than this.

column1: I first read the Dance Hall of the Dead in high school.  Being a member of the Zuni Tribe
column2: and a resident of the town of Zuni
column3: it was quite interesting to see how much of the information concerning Zuni could be changed to fit the "theme" and plot of the book.  While these may seem like little details to most people
column4: it is quite disturbing to see how often Hillermans work is seen as accurate
column5: because of a reputation he has somehow gained as an "expert" on Native Cultures of the American Southwest.  Apparently
column6: he thought that all pueblo people are the same.  This is evident in the use of the last name of Cata
column7: which is not even seen in Zuni
column8: and is actually a last name seen only in the Rio Grande Pueblos.  In addition
column9: his interpretation or portrayal of the Sha'la'k'o ceremony as a "Dance Hall of the Dead" is simplistic at best.  While he may be an "expert" in Navajo culture
column10: it does not qualify him to comment on a COMPLETELY different society
column11: much less its sacred and complex kachina ceremonies.  Finally
column12: many native people
column13: such as the Navajo
column14: the Zuni and the Hopi (who have all been "featured" in Hillerman's books) feel that Hillerman's descriptions of ceremonies and rituals is just plain wrong.  As an outsider
column15: he has no business delving into or exposing the nature of such things as kachinas
column16: which we consider sacred yet dangerous.  Furthermore
column17: by exploiting our cultures for the sake of adding interest to a plot
column18: he seems to show a lack of respect for our cultures
column19: our religions
column20: and our tribes in general.   This in itself is bad enough
column21: but the worst thing is that people actually consider his novels definitive descriptions of Native culture.  There are many ethnological works out there that are available
column22: and they are NOT hard to find.  After all Zuni is one of
column23: if not THE most complex
column24: and most studied society on earth.  While I don't agree with people wanting to know "everything there is to know" about Zuni culture
column25: there are much better places to find out about "us" than a Tony Hillerman book

column1: May be as damaging as out and out lies.  I think Crichton is a fine writer who could have written a great novel about the manipulation of a populace through media and other networks.  Instead we have a hodge podge story that jumps around the Earth as the theses it posits jump around the truth.  One of these that I found most disturbing was the Antagonists statement that DDT was not proven to be harmful.  Maybe so
column2: but the chemical reaction (something that happens quite often in nature) DDT has with some soils leads to DDE which is very harmful to native species.    It reminds me of Bowling for Columbine.  Whether you like Micheal Moore or not
column3: he had a thesis about how afraid Americans are made to feel.  Why do you lock your door at night?  If someone wants to get in
column4: they will.  Moore touches on
column5: but does not get in depth with the pervasiveness of fear in American society.    Crichton does the same while attempting to discredit many environmental groups. He portrays these organizations very well
column6: however
column7: the story never really develops into an in depth investigation of what really terrorizes our society and why that fear drives us to consume
column8: ultimately leading to our very real fear of a society that is one of the safest in the world. (check the FBI website to see how crimes have fallen and show that really we are safer than we were 40 years ago!).

column1: Prior to buying this phone I had heard a lot of people say that Motorola's hardware was very good
column2: but that their software left a lot to be desired.  Nonetheless I decided to try this phone out when it came time to start a new cell plan.  I had made the decision to switch to T-mobile and this looked like one of the best phone options.  Right off the bat I found out that the people who criticized Moto's software were right on the money.  There are a host of poorly designed software aspects of this phone
column3: not the least of which is the -- frankly -- idiotic way the phone book is designed.  Eventually I made peace with all of the things I disliked about the V360 since at least it seemed to work well enough as a phone.    As time went by I started noticing that I was missing a lot of calls.  The phone would be in my bag or in my pocket or sitting on my desk when suddenly it would ring with the voicemail notification from a message that I had received anywhere from minutes to hours before.  During the course of the last few months (the phone is less than a year old) I've also found that it has begun crashing.  A lot.  Opening or closing it will result in a "white screen of death."  Putting it on the charger will cause it to switch back and forth between the messages that it is charging
column4: that it is unable to charge and that it's SIM card cannot be found
column5: after a few minutes of which it will simply shut itself off.  With a full battery charge it will continually shut itself off.    At this point I am forced to conclude that this phone is an absolute piece of junk.  I am also forced to conclude that it isn't the only model which is.  None of my coworkers has ever had a good experience with a Motorola phone.  My wife's Motorola has shown its own host of problems.  People working for T-mobile at several stores I have visited have confided that they never
column6: ever recommend Motorola phones to anyone.  In fact I've had T-mobile employees urge me to not buy any phones from them
column7: but rather to shop for an unlocked Nokia online.  So that's what I'm going to do.    Until I can buy a new phone all I can do is recharge this phone every night
column8: restart it five or six times a day
column9: and keep apologizing to my friends
column10: family and employers for always missing their calls

column1: I've been under the weather this weekend
column2: and spent most of my time in bed. This sucked. However
column3: my loving wife was kind enough to run to the library and grab some reading material
column4: so at least I had that option.  Sadly
column5: I spent a good portion of that time reading Beaujon's lackluster attempt at a definitive sample of Christian Rock.  Want the short capsule review? This book is weak sauce
column6: written by someone not qualified to write such a work
column7: and with an agenda to pound.  Now for the long review.  My biggest complaint with BPSML is that the whole premise is weak. That premise being "Let's take a contributing writer from Spin magazine (a magazine not known for its favorable view of Christian music) send him around to a few music festivals and see if he can figure out what makes those kooky Christians tick!"  That's hardly a compelling pitch for a book. Honestly
column8: I don't know who would buy it. I doubt Christians are champing at the bit to hear yet again that the secular world distrusts and misunderstands them. Likewise
column9: if you aren't already a fan of CCM
column10: where's the motivation to read this? You aren't going to recognize any of the bands.  Secondly
column11: Beaujon is not at all qualified to write this kind of work. At least not without doing research that he doesn't bother with. This is evident throughout the book is many ways two of the more glaring being his mistaking the parable of the Prodigal Son for the parable of the Good Samaritan. Hey
column12: if you're going to be writing about artists using these stories as fuel for their music
column13: don't you think you should know the difference?  One other way Beaujon shows his lack of qualifications to write this work is in his flawed insider's view of the music world. I don't think I'm alone in feeling that most music critics (critics in general for that matter) love to champion the exotic and outr
column14: even if such work just simply sucks. I don't know why this phenomenon exists
column15: but you can see it in any issue of Spin or Rolling Stone you pick up. Half-baked bands with bizarre sounds and near pornographic stage shows become media darlings
column16: while quiet solid performers are ignored and languish in obscurity. How else to explain the overwhelming fame of Marilyn Manson
column17: and the near anonymity of Michael Penn?  Beaujon brings this insider's prejudice to his take on Christian rock as well - lauding acts like Pedro the Lion for creative use of profanity
column18: and reveling in tales of those CCM artists who have suffered personal moral setbacks. At times he seems almost giddy in his revelation that by golly
column19: some of these Jesus Freaks smoke
column20: drink and cuss! How novel!  Additionally Beaujon takes an almost hit and miss sample of Christian rock. Claiming bands that he likes are the "Big Show" and utterly ignoring those he doesn't appreciate. I'm sorry
column21: but writing about Christian music and ignoring the excellent work of Steven Curtis Chapman
column22: is like writing a history of secular rock
column23: and neglecting to include at least a mention of Michael Jackson and Thriller. To make matters worse
column24: the bands Beaujon chooses to see are predominantly part of the Jesus People movement
column25: and play the Cornerstone festival. He hits a few acts from Tooth & Nail too. Good stuff to be sure
column26: but far from a real sampling of Christian Rock.  The reader is thus left with a very one-sided view of CCM
column27: and that view is flawed and filtered through Beaujon's own opinions. It appalled me to read Beaujon's high praise for Stryper (a mediocre hair metal band that had a few albums in 80's) immediately followed by his utter scorn for Petra. He even goes so far as to call Petra bereft of musical talent. Sorry Andrew
column28: Petra's been around far too long to be dissed like that. They've earned their chops
column29: and survived multiple shakeups in the band. Untalented? No. Might not be your cup of tea
column30: but remember what we're talking about here
column31: a Christian band performing stadium style rock anthems and power ballads. You can't really compare them to flavor of the moment groups like Mute Math. I defy anyone to compare Petra to Aerosmith and KISS and find them demonstrably less talented.  In Beaujon's defense
column32: he admits that he interviewed the bands he did
column33: because they were the few that would speak with him. Most act's publicists just dumped his call into limbo. It amuses me that he seems baffled by this behavior
column34: touting secular acts outstanding availability to the press. Gee Andy
column35: why would Christian artists be hesitant to be interviewed by a Spin writer? Could it be that they've done it before and been brutalized in the media? Could it be that they're used to being marginalized by the mainstream
column36: and have no incentive to help promote your book? Could it be that your readers simply aren't their target audience/market
column37: and they just plain don't need you?  Should these artists have been so wary? In a word - absolutely.  From the first word
column38: Beaujon is pushing his agenda. He cleverly doesn't admit this until the afterword though. In fact
column39: if you questioned him about it
column40: I doubt he'd even realize that he was writing from a specific agenda. Simply put
column41: Beaujon suffers from a malady that afflicts far too many people in this world. Once upon a time
column42: someone who claimed to be a Christian hurt them
column43: and as such
column44: they tar all Christians with the same shady brush. In Beaujon's case
column45: it was his father
column46: a minister driven from his church after having an affair with a parishioner
column47: then embezzling from the next church he went to. Do I feel sorry that Beaujon had to go through that as a child? Sure. That's a terrible thing for anyone to live through. Beaujon admits that this led him to question his faith and reject God.  Let me pause here to comment on this scenario. As I said
column48: this type of thing happens far too often. The only response I can make is to say that first
column49: Christians aren't perfect. And it wasn't Jesus that hurt you
column50: just one of his followers.  With this type of baggage in his past
column51: it's surprising that Beaujon is as fair as he manages. I was pleasantly surprised that he simply didn't conclude that CCM is a farce
column52: and all believers are fools - hey
column53: I've heard it before from better writers!  This bias proves out time and time again in BPSML. As I mentioned before
column54: Beaujon takes an almost perverse glee in citing case after case of Christian rocker that stumbled in the game
column55: and gave in to moral weakness. Amy Grant had a divorce and sunbathes nude! Sandy Patty had an affair! POD don't want to be called a Christian band! David Bazan doesn't even think he's a Christian anymore!  So what? These aren't cases unique to CCM. They happen all the time in all walks of life. What really seems to puzzle Beaujon is why the Christian rock community takes these cases so seriously. He scoffs at so called "morals clauses" in artist contracts that call for them to abstain from vice and immorality. Why is that such a bad idea? If the secular music world adopted such clauses
column56: maybe there's be a few more Janis Joplins
column57: Jimi Hendrix
column58: and Kurt Cobains around?  He also sees no merit in record labels that try to help new acts fit into the CCM scene. He mocks the so-called "Jesus-per-minute" requirements many labels enforce. First off
column59: I doubt such requirements can be boiled down to something as simplistic as a "Jesus-per-minute" or "no bad language" requirement. Secondly
column61: why is this a problem? Doesn't it make sense far a label to shelter a new act a little? This is just professionalism in my opinion. For example
column62: suppose I was appointed Surgeon General of the United States. In my first public address
column63: I walk on stage in a Nazi uniform and give a speech about how "We're going to commit genocide on AIDS!" That kind of behavior is blatantly inappropriate for the job. So too would be a Christian band that wants to write songs that make no mention of spiritual truth
column64: and consistently use profanity. Pedro the Lion ... I'm looking right at you.  I'll give Beaujon a few points. He nails the impact of Keith Green right on the head. He also does an excellent job denoting the impact of Steve Taylor. These are both artists that made a huge mark in the world of Christian rock
column65: and Beaujon rightly spends ample time on both of them.  In summary though
column66: I just can't recommend this book. If you're already a fan of CCM
column67: picking up a few copies of CCM Magazine will give you a better overview of the genre. If you don't like CCM at all
column68: why would you even read this book? Beaujon makes an attempt at being non-judgmental
column69: but his own baggage and bias trip him up. He winds up writing a book that is neither hot nor cold
column71: and just like the Laodiceans in Revelation 3
column72: I want to spew this mess of a book out of my mouth

column1: This is a problem I've had for some time with Conor Oberst
column2: front-man of Bright Eyes. He is undoubtedly
column3: perhaps even unusually
column4: talented as a young songwriter. At the age of 13
column5: he was released his own debut album on cassette and had started his own record label with his brother. He had already released a sizable catalogue of work by the time he was 25
column6: when "I'm Wide Awake
column7: It's Morning" and "Digital Ash in a Digital Urn" were both released at the same time. It may be bizarre to release two separate albums at once
column8: when they could've just as easily been packaged together in a double-album. This is the sort of abstract "cleverness" that I find slightly irritating.  "I'm Wide Awake
column9: It's Morning"
column10: a collection of guitar-based folk songs
column11: is nearly the opposite of "Digital Ash in a Digital Urn"
column12: a more electronic
column13: alternative-style album. The intention of releasing two separate albums appears to be to showcase Oberst's ability to make two entirely different styles of music. Oberst has been considered a "musical genius" and "prodigy" by many of his long-time fans and critics. I find that this is perhaps an over-estimate of his abilities. Yes
column14: we already know that he's come out with a large quantity of music for his age. But
column15: how much of it is good?  "I'm Wide Awake
column16: It's Morning" is essentially a folksy
column17: "story-telling" sort of album. The first song
column18: "At The Bottom of Everything" opens with Oberst's narrative tale of a woman on an airplane about to crash into the ocean
column19: before the music and lyrical part of the song actually starts. The rest of the songs are in the same vein
column20: each telling a story through the lyrics and background music. Some fans have made comparisons between Oberst's style and Bob Dylan
column21: which I don't think is fair. Bob Dylan
column22: influential folk-song performer of the 60s
column23: has an effortless style of song composition and a capability of writing songs of a variety of themes
column24: including messages of political relevance. Oberst
column25: on the other hand
column26: is trying incredibly hard to really make something of himself. He often comes across as rather desperate to reach some sort of apex of musical genius
column27: after which I suppose he assumes to be praised for his talent.  I don't think I'm even going to bother writing a review for "Digital Ash in a Digital Urn"
column28: because it's not really worth my time. "I'm Wide Awake
column29: It's Morning" is better composed and contains greater amount of listenable songs than the other. There are times when his true talent becomes apparent
column30: as in the well-crafted and catchy 'Another Travelin' Song'
column31: but many of the others come across as exceedingly forced and lacking in depth. He still has an huge amount of potential
column32: but I don't think it will come through until he stops trying so hard to stun and amaze music-listeners with such feats as releasing two albums simultaneously (however lackluster they may be!). I find that it is the quality of the music that matters the most
column33: not the volume of material produced

column1: The author argues that we Americans have been throwing our weight around.  And that we ought to embrace multilateralism and international law.  Well
column2: that sounds really good.  Just what could be wrong with that?    The main problem is that even if we Americans have been unfair and unjust
column3: there is little reason to believe that we'll be better off if we give more power to an international group.  Such a group could be united against us
column4: and it could make things worse for everyone (and really bad for us Americans).  Probably
column5: we'd be assured at the start of the group's good intentions.  But after we conceded enough power
column6: we'd get double-crossed.  Well
column7: there isn't too much chance of that!  The United Nations
column8: the International Criminal Court
column9: and others have made their intentions pretty clear.  And so does the author.  We're talking about a wolf in wolf's clothing.  I think one important issue the author deals with is the Arab-Israeli conflict.  As he says
column10: "On no issue is the gulf between America and the rest of the world greater than on" this.  Well
column11: given that the issue is so important
column12: what does Prestowitz say?    Well
column13: he refuses to blame the Arab side for the failure of the Camp David negotiations.  And he says that Sharon's walk on the Temple Mount was about as bad an idea as one could have.  Okay
column14: I have a few questions:  1)  If the Arab case has any merit
column15: why is it promoted almost exclusively by terror and lies?  Does he think that such terror and lies ought to be opposed?  2)  Why does the author think it proper to ethnically cleanse Jews (but not Arabs) from the West Bank?  Isn't that a little arbitrary?  And why does the author think this injustice is essential to bring peace closer?  3)  Given that plenty of members of the Knesset had been visiting the Temple Mount
column16: why does the author think that a pre-approved visit by Sharon was so obviously a bad idea?  Has it occurred to him that refusing to let Sharon do something so ordinary might have severe ramifications in itself?  And just why is it that the author feels that a Jew visiting the holiest Jewish site
column17: in the capital of Israel ought to be a casus belli?  Does this mean that the author thinks that Jews ought to be special in not having any rights in their own capital or at their own holy sites?  Oh yes
column18: some folks have boasted that the author is a conservative.  But I'm judging his book on its merits
column19: not on the author's purported politics.  In any case
column20: I'm a liberal.  Had the author been more honest with us
column21: I think I'd have been more willing to look at his advice.  As it stands
column22: I think the one star I'm giving this book is generous

column1: I found this textbook to be utter garbage and a complete and confused mess.  Easily the worst text book out of my recent courses.(Campbell's Biology and Pasachoff's Physics are world's better.  I find it difficult to believe this is about as good of a book as an organic chem professor can write.  Very sad if this were true.)  A dearth of example problems make learning this far more difficult than it need to be.  This is made worse given the fact the problems for students at the end of the chapter don't build up bit by bit from earlier portions of the chapter until it ties it all together.  That's not even discussing just how few of these problems have any answer in the back of the book.(Since it's so easy to get a completely wrong but reasonable looking answer that's a big problem and pretty much means the solution manual has to be bought with it.  Almost seems like a scam to trick students out of over $200 by splitting the cost between two books.)  Also I get the impression that the authors have a crippling phobia of math and equations.(Just look at the end of chapter 7 where 2 pages of text could have been replaced by the equation for doing a SODAR calculation.)  Just utter garbage which isn't good given that organic is trying enough as it is

column1: I am giving Truffaut's interview with Hitchcock a single star because it has been revered as "the" book on this master director for way too long.   I first read this book years ago as a new student of film and Hitchcock.  Since that time I have read lots more about Hitchcock and with each new piece of the puzzle
column2: have determined after re-reading it recently that there is little that is new or exclusive to this book.  Hitchcock often told the same stories elsewhere
column3: both before and after publication of this book some thirty plus years ago.  The books sole value is as an entertainment
column4: or as a Hitchcock-primer.  This book merely provides what Hitchcock wanted to say of himself
column5: the packaged image
column6: just like his famous caricature.  There are many other books to choose from which offer a more complete portrait.  Seek them out ..

column1: We purchased the crib
column2: armoire
column3: & dresser w/ tower & it took 5 wks for this to be shipped to us. Once we received it
column4: we opened it only to find that each box contained 2-3 severely  cracked pieces. After inspecting them
column5: we found that the dmg wasn't caused by packaging but
column6: poor craftsmanship. Most pieces were assembled using a nailgun & some of the nails were even bent. The cracking stemmed from areas that had been nailed & continued all the way up the piece of furniture. Had the co pre drilled the holes & used screws instead
column7: this would've never happended. Obviously it's "cheaper" to use nails instead of screws. We took pictures of the dmgs & I wish I could  attach them to this review so you'd be able to see for yourself. There were also several areas inside the crib which weren't sanded properly & would be a real hazard for little fingers b/c of splintering wood. It was advertised to be constructed of hardwoods
column8: but in all actuality it's pine. When you think of hardwood
column9: you expect oak or birch
column10: not a softwood like pine. The tops of the furniture & the drawer fronts were the only pieces that were solid wood. Everything else was particle board. Some of the solid wood pieces weren't even 1 piece of wood
column11: but 3 & they were glued together. We're currently trying to return this product for a full refund. We're also shopping last minute for replacement furniture w/ only 2 wks left before my due date. I would never purchase a another peice of furniture made by this company again.

column1: I have read many of N.B.'s novels and essays
column2: and he is a favorite author of mine.  This novel
column3: however
column4: seems more like it was written by someone else in his writing style
column5: rather than written by Baker himself.  It lacks the substantive punch of his earlier works
column6: lacks the beauty and emotion of a narrator relating to others in his world.  The pet duck in the story seems more real
column7: compelling
column8: and finely drawn than the narrator's wife and children.  (Maybe this is intentional?)  In addition
column9: whereas past Baker narrators have described the minutiae of their lives with freshness and wonder
column10: this narrator gets pedantic.  Does the reader really need to be told how a rear-window defroster works
column11: or how to wash a dish?  I think for Baker fans
column12: this might be a disappointment.  For a first-time Baker reader
column13: however
column14: it's a peaceful little book that might lead to his better ones.

column1: Lian Hearn lost me on this one.  This is the third and final book of the original Tales of the Otori trilogy (there's a fourth book set decades after this one ends that reportedly resolves the one dangling issue from the trilogy) and it is easily the worst.  Across the Nightingale Floor was very good with swift pacing
column2: a mentally tough heroine and solid action; Grass for his Pillow was a decent middle volume that moved the story forward
column3: set up the final book and did not lose too much momentum.  Brilliance of the Moon is a relative flop.  The two main characters
column4: Takeo and Kaede
column5: make laughably stupid decisions.  Kaede loses too much of her inner strength -- she becomes simply the damsel in distress.  And the anti-climactic
column6: deus ex machina resolution to Takeo's quest is entirely too unsatisfying.    If you can read Book 1 and enjoy it as a stand-alone novel despite its status as the first in a trilogy/tetralogy
column7: do so.  But you're forewarned before you get too deep into the story
column8: the ending in this volume is pure disappointment

column1: This is the first (and last) book by David Baldacci that I've ever read. He is one of the worst best-selling writers I've ever read. He writes almost every sentence of dialog in the form of a Tom Swifty sentence ("We've got to get out of here
column2: said King, menacingly). His flair for melodramatic overstatement is second to none. The actions of the characters make no sense at all. For example, when Michelle sees a laser from a gun sight pointed at the chest of her trusty sidekick, Sean King, she says, Sean
column3: don't move!" instead of "Sean
column4: dive for cover!!!" Bottom line - save your money and buy something worthwhile

column1: This past August
column2: I had bought the soundtrack to Pete Townsend's 1989 musical The Iron Man
column3: which was also based on Ted Hughes's 1968 novel
column4: and was impressed not only with Mr. Townsend's artistry
column5: but also with the wisdom of the message that its songs conveyed as individual selections on an entire album that was just plain fun to listen to. Naturally
column6: I thus came to thinking that maybe this motion picture
column7: which was released a whole decade after that particular CD
column8: would likely appeal to my imagination in the same way the musical would have
column9: had I only the opportunity to see the latter presentation myself. Unfortunately
column10: I found out how wrong I was when I rented this rightfully less-than-appreciated flick last weekend and forced myself to sit through it.  Now
column11: I'll admit
column12: the animation was definitely something worthy of applause; that's the ONE thing I'll give The Iron Giant credit for. However
column13: that's as far as my praise for this movie goes. I'll also admit that it didn't follow the exact same lines as either the book or the musical
column14: but then again
column15: I was expecting that to be the case. Rather
column16: it was the overall tone of the film that earned my enmity. To begin with
column17: though I am well aware that many animated features and other family-themed features contain the occasional sight gag or adult-themed joke
column18: TIG seemed to be heavily punctuated with them
column19: from beatnik scrap-sculptor Dean McChoppin unzipping his fly to let young Hogarth Hughes's "pet" squirrel escape his pants to the "bathroom" scene where Hogarth tries to cover for the robot's hand as it exits the Hughes's home--the latter scene of which has AT LEAST two instances of what one could easily call "toilet-bowl humor." Not only that
column20: but I found the protagonist himself to be just the most obnoxious and repulsive example of a lead character I have ever come to know: a loud
column21: unruly
column22: disobedient brat reminiscent of all four of young Charlie Bucket's tourmates from Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory who tries to pass himself off as having more depth than he really has. Honestly
column23: he's NOT what I would call "amiable
column24: heart-warming
column25: or even cute"; such adjectives I'd rather reserve for the wide-eyed
column26: honest
column27: poverty-stricken Mr. Bucket. Of course
column28: it's not like I really appreciated any of the other human characters in this flick
column29: either--not little Mr. Hughes's ridiculously clueless diner waitress mother Annie
column30: nor the deadbeat wannabe "artist" Dean
column31: nor even the inept government agent whose name I have completely (yet thankfully) forgotten despite his being the most complex Earthling participant in the entire cartoon. As such
column32: only the hundred-foot-tall
column33: metal-munching robot--a softhearted and self-maintaining (if nonetheless hopelessly brain-damaged) extraterrestrial being who has no memory at all of his origin--impressed me. Even so
column34: the movie portrayed the poor guy as being so incredibly dimwitted (as opposed to being haplessly misguided and a tad naive
column35: which I was hoping he'd come off as being) in an effort to make him likeable to the kids in the audience that I ended up pitying him more than anything else. Needless to say
column36: then
column37: as much as I tried to grapple with each and every one of these elements as they presented themselves
column38: I merely found it harder and harder to get over and accept them all as a collective whole
column39: and I ended up returning this movie to the video store in utter disgust.  Believe me
column40: ladies and gentlemen
column41: I really tried to appreciate The Iron Giant
column42: but despite my efforts in trying to see the side of the story that its fans see in it
column43: all was for naught
column44: and now I am left asking myself as to just why I even bothered to rent it in the first place. After all
column45: it has been known to be one of a number of very unpopular motion pictures from 1999
column46: and with good reason: It caters to a very low level of mentality
column47: even amongst the underdeveloped minds of the kids for whom it was made. Tragically
column48: so do many other movies these days
column49: regardless of how successful or unsuccessful they are--a current
column50: seven-plus-year-long fad that honestly disturbs me and gets me wondering about the sensibility of the average person these days. Worse yet is how a movie as plagued with such lowbrow buffoonery as this one would have a "special edition" on DVD five years after its initial release--especially considering how allegedly few people have actually seen it. Oh
column51: well...I still wish I could've seen Pete Townsend's Iron Man musical. At least THAT would have been something worth witnessing

column1: I purchased this product to replace a really good 802.11g unit from Linksys
column2: hoping to set up a Gigabit home network with ethernet storage.  I initially considered the WRT300N model
column3: but the reviews were mediocre.  So I went instead for this newer model
column4: hoping that Linksys has fixed the bugs and addressed the problems identified with the WRT300N model.  I am sorry to say that all the bad reviews on the WRT300N also apply to this model.  I am returning it after 5 hours of use.  On my home network set up with my current Linksys 802.11g unit
column5: I am able to stream 4 different movies to four different laptops at the same time throughout the house
column6: and all four movies display flawlessly.  On this new unit optimized for streaming video
column7: I was not able to stream a movie to a single laptop sitting close to the wireless unit.  The movie had interruptions every 4-5 seconds.  This was worse as the laptop was positioned further from the wireless unit.  Performance was equally bad with laptops equiped with G cards and N cards.  And performance degraded as I tried to stream to multiple laptops at the same time.  The speed of the links to my laptops equiped with N cards was 144 Mb/s
column8: and was 54 Mb/s on those equiped with G cards.  So the connection seemed fast enough.  It might be that by tweaking the wireless unit in some way
column9: it might be able to perform as I expect.  But I don't have time to waste on such tweaking
column10: and given that my 802.11g unit performed flawlessly out of the box
column11: there is no point to "upgrade" to this new flawed model.  I'll delay my plans for a gigabit home network until the technology has matured and the bugs have been worked out

column24: this is 1986

column1: Initially intrigued with this book
column2: I quickly lost interest.  It starts out well but then degenerates into a bunch of random points which the author tries to use to argue his hypothesis that the universe was designed to give rise to intelligent life as a final outcome.  The blurbs along the margin were major distractions & made it hard to stay focused on the actual material in the book.  The book just kind of wanders around the various fields of science trying to find evidence to support the author's premise and then ends with the pronouncement that we're the peak of creation (very Genesis-like).  I'd have to pronounce this book mildly interesting if you can wade through the claptrap and the biased agenda

column1: Sam is shocked when her husband decides he wants to divorce
column2: even though she knew they had been growing apart for some time.  The news crushes her
column3: and she deals with it by going to Tiffany's and spending $12
column4: 00.00 on things she doesn't really want.  Her husband's response is mild exasperation and a warning that he's moved most of the money out of the checking account where it will be safe.  Are you kidding me?  Are these supposed to be real people acting this way?  What follows is a series of events of unbelievable good luck as Sam alternates between feeling sorry for herself and acting absolutely crazy in a quest to be the perfect housewife and mother. A good example of the latter is when she cooks an entire Thanksgiving dinner
column5: including a twenty-one pound turkey and several pies
column6: although she is spending the day entirely alone.  Despite her erratic behavior
column7: Sam manages to find the perfect woman to move in with her--a grandmotherly woman who helps her recover from her heartache.  Sam also begins a series of temp jobs and meets a brilliant and sweet man who loves her enough to totally change himself for her.  Throughout everything
column8: Sam's husband continues to support her financially.  They don't fight over their son and her husband is even tolerant of Sam's crazy phone calls.  If this is what divorced life is like
column9: I'm surprised more women don't go for it.

column1: Described as
column2: "loosely based on the life of Janis Joplin
column3: The Rose would be much more entertaining if the film makers had gotten the rights to Joplins songs.  Bette Midler does an incredible job of re-creating a life of turmoil through the eyes of a sixties rock diva. An exhausted, burned out alcoholic who begs her promoter/manager (played by Alan Bates,) to give her a year off to rest, The Rose
column4: is on the path of destruction.  When she hooks up with an AWOL Vietnam War Veteran, you find yourself hoping he can calm her down enough to save her, but of course, you know that won't happen.  Much of the movie is actual concert footage of Midler singing her heart out, doing Janis Joplin like
column5: tunes, but again, this movie misses something by not using the real stuff.  And, as well as Midler belts out the songs, she sounds like Bette Midler singing 60's rock anthems and bluesy ballads; she doesn't sound like Janis Joplin at all.  Of course, Bette Midler doesn't look anything like Joplin, either.  Midler is a red-headed Jewish girl and Joplin was a bushy haired brunette from Port Charles, LA.  So, there are no physical similarities whatsoever between the real Janis Joplin and The Rose."  The movie is somewhat dated by now
column6: and I for one would like to see a newer
column7: more accurate version being released for todays audiences.

column1: This book is a joke.  It is written by a guy who has followed Colin Powell around and has taken a lot of notes on what he has said.  He then put together a bunch of Powell's stories and comments into this book.  The "secrets" are not secrets at all.  They are common sense to most people.  After the first couple of chapters I realized that I was wasting my time trying to read each word and just went to the summaries at the end of each chapter.  It's all summed up there.  Powell did not contribute to this book
column2: he was merely a speaker who fed the author enough information to pull this book together

column1: More Than Human is one of those books that has garnered high praise from the science fiction community because of its strong prose and original ideas.  The writing is often compared to that of Faulkner but I wouldn't make that connection having read a few of Faulkner's works.  Sturgeon uses many of Faulkner's narrative trademarks (i.e. streaming conscious
column2: first person perspective of low IQ individuals
column3: disorienting changes in first person narrative) but I didn't feel the net effect really compared to say something like As I Lay Dying.  I love science fiction books and the readers in general love the genre which is why they want it to be taken seriously.  This results in undue adulation and comparisons to mainstream books.  More Than Human is slow
column4: dated and not what I would describe as genre transcending nor would I recommend it to others.  So the idea might of been original in the 50's but topics like telekenesis
column5: ESP
column6: computer-brain babies
column7: and self produced morality and ethos have all been tackled more successfully in other science fiction classics before (Asimov) and since.  This book rarely set off that wow! button in my head or kept me turning pages.  This book simply did not have enough meat in it to make it anything more than mediocre at best.  In 1953 there were 5 Hugo Award nominees for best science fiction book (Determined in a retro hugo award ballot in 2004)  The Retro Hugo awards are fascinating because the voting (in this example) takes place 50 years later so the impact of the book on society can't really be ignored.  Besides More Than Human
column8: the far superior The Caves Of Steel
column9: Childhood's End
column10: and Farenheit 451 were among the other entries in a banner year for classic sci-fi.  Needless to say
column11: More Than Human did not win (Farenheit 451 did and rightfully so)  Bottom Line:  I wanted to like this book and it doesn't surprise me that others give it such high praise.  These are probably people that don't read other genres enjoy congratulatory wankfests

column1: The author of this book openly avows that he isn't a historian
column2: but something tells me I would have known even if he hadn't.  This book is dotted with many examples of practices that would make anyone even vaguely interested in accurate history cringe.  For example
column3: Shirazi describes the Scythians/Sakas as being "pagans who held their women in common and devoured their aged relatives" on page 85.  However
column4: he neglects to note that because the Scythians had no writing of their own
column5: the only accounts of them we have were written by the Greeks and the Persians - i.e. their bitter enemies who probably weren't particularly interested in scholarly objectivity.  He also tends to make rather large omissions
column6: one example being the complete lack of reference to Shah Ismail's brutal campaign of forcing the public to convert from Sunnism to Shi'ism in the chapter on the Safavid Empire.  Last but not least
column7: he has an irritating tendency to make embarrassing factual errors
column8: a few of which I'll list:  - Page 64: Referring to Cyrus the Great as Cyrus III when he was actually Cyrus II - Page 88: Reference to the assassination of Julius Caesar at the hands of Octavius and Cassius rather than Brutus and Cassius - Page 203: Calling Ahmad Pasha "the Turk Emperor
column9: despite that he was only a military officer and later a governor and despite that the very title pasha indicates that he was a government functionary, not a sultan - Page 216: Reference to how Thomas Jefferson along with other scholars drew up the [U.S.] Constitution" despite Jefferson's being in France at the time and thus obviously not well placed to attend a constitutional convention in Philadelphia  There are other claims that seem questionable
column10: such as the assertion on page 188 that the Ottoman sultan Selim I massacred 40
column11: 000 Shi'ites for which I have yet to find any corroborating sources.  However
column12: those I listed above were enough to make me suspect every fact this book offered.    I suppose one can argue that this proves the superior instructive ability of the book (the process of running to the internet every five minutes to crosscheck a claim did ensure the subject matter was drilled into my memory)
column13: but this is hardly what constitutes an undisputed authority on the subject.  Of course
column14: the book does have one undisputable edge over other histories of Iran: it's in English (albeit rather bad English).  However
column15: if the reader wants a history that doesn't require constantly being on the alert for inaccuracies
column16: this is not the place to look

column1: THOU SHALT NOT was a disappointing show because the source material (THERESE RAQUIN) has the potential to be a powerful musical.  Harry Connick Jr. penned the words and music for this show
column2: yet it seems he has never studied some of the Broadway classics (from OKLAHOMA! thru RAGTIME) to learn how to use songs to develop character and advance the story.  He has come up with some great tunes here
column3: but rarely do they seem to have much in common with the tragic story.  One notable exception is "The Other Hours" which is perfectly suited to the moment.  "Take her to the Mardi Gras" is a geat up-tempo dance number
column4: but much of the rest plays like a collection of songs rater than numbers which are part of an integrated story.  Connick says he hopes to continue to work on Broadway and as I write this in March 2006 he is starring in a smash-hit revival of PAJAMA GAME.  Broadway can certainly use a composer of his talent
column5: and we can only hope that he learns how to weave story and character into his songs for a future musical.  The cast on this CD is first-rate: Nobert Leo Butz
column6: Craig Bierko
column7: Kate Levering
column8: Debra Monk are all fine. The CD is well-produced but the booklet contains only the lyrics and no notes about the show or a synopsis. Also no label or catalogue number. It seems to be a private release.  Copies were sent to Tony voters when the score was nominated (it lost to URINETOWN)and then with little fanfare the CD started showing up on Amazon and other web-retailers and in speciatly shops like New York's Footlight Records
column9: but it has never been given general distribution.  Was this prduction jinxed? Previews had to be delayed a week because of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.  Opening night Craig Bierko was accidently hit in the throat durring a fight scene and was out of the show for 2 weeks.  Kate Levering spained an ankle and was also forced out of the show for a  spell.  Maybe the ghost of Camille Raquin is more powerful than we thought

column1: Louise Gluck is one of those bland poets that happened to be in the right place at the right time. That this bland book has won a pulitzer just shows how the quality doesn't matter
column2: but rather WHO is getting it. These poems are filled with teenaged cliches "I speak because I am shattered"
column3: "At the end of my suffering
column4: there was a door
column5:
etc. Totally banal, generic, and poorly broken with an occasional puff of language here or there. Really these 'poems' are just prose broken into lines. Her imagry is dull, and not really worth discussion. The reviewers who 'liked' this book do just that, since there is no critical logic that can be applied to these 'poems' to even remotely call them good. Gluck is a total lightweight, one that will, once dead, be recycled to the cannon of late 20th cent. literary fodder of one of those yet again, another overrated pulitzer winner with so little to show for it. A prise can no longer be worth much if this is the mediocrity that is winning it. And yes, I am right about this. 
 Many of the ideas in this book are very contradicting to the bible however he does bring up some good points. Read C.S. Lewis' responce to this book entiteled The Great Divorce"

column1: Having read a few of Anne Tyler's books in the past
column2: I was looking forward to reading her latest novel.  At best
column3: I found the book to be wholly forgettable.  At worst
column4: I found her bottom line premises
column5: upon which the book is based
column6: without much merit.  I say so with some personal insight.  I was born in America in 1944
column7: the first in my family to be a native born American.  And yes
column8: my parents spoke a "foreign" language at home
column9: among themselves and with their friends and relatives.  I was schooled in the local public schools
column10: and interacted with youngsters who came from all sorts of backgrounds.  This remained true as I went on to college
column11: and then graduate school.  My family did not feel like it was outside of the American mainstream because they had their roots in Europe.  To the contrary
column12: they felt blessed to be here
column13: and never missed an opportunity to praise America and all it stood for.  While our parents spoke a concocted language to us (we called it Germglish)
column14: we fully understood their native tongue
column15: while we (the children) only conversed in English (to them as well as to others). Our experience was not unique;  infact
column16: most of the people we met came from similar homes and backgrounds.  Now
column17: perhaps growing up in New York City is different from living in the Baltimore suburbs
column18: but I don't really think so.  I think that the greatest thing about this country lies in the fact that ALL of us came from somewhere
column19: either recently or once upon a time.  And while we may choose to interact with people who share similar backgrounds
column20: I really can't imagine that most of us are embarassed that we are not the American stereotype...white
column21: protestant
column22: having ancestors who came over on the Mayflower.  For this reason
column23: more than any other
column24: I found the book to be based on faulty premises
column25: and when the central feature of a book doesn't ring true
column26: the whole book ends up being less than fulfilling.
